author: TOM SHERIDAN
title: MENIFEE: Hundreds line streets to honor fallen Marine veteran
text:
BY TOM SHERIDAN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: 10:03 p.m. LAST RESPECTS • Menifee resident Christopher Ruiz, a Marine veteran, died in a the crash of an Air Force transport plane in Afghanistan earlier this month.
• His remains were returned home on Saturday, escorted to a mortuary in Menifee by a procession that included Patriot Guard Riders.
• Ruiz, who was 29, is survived by his wife, Lorelyn, 29, and three children: Brooklyn, 5; Carter, 3; and Aria, 1.
• The cause of the crash at Jalalabad air field on Oct. 2 is still being investigated.
When word got out that Menifee resident Christopher Ruiz died in a plane crash in Afghanistan earlier this month it touched many in the community that he and his wife have called home for the last six years.
Ruiz, working for a defense contractor at the time of his death, was a Marine veteran who is survived by a wife and three young children.
As a funeral hearse carried his remains home Saturday morning, Oct. 10, hundreds of people in the community interrupted their weekend routines to line a street next to the I-215, waving flags and holding signs to honor the local man who lost his life serving his country.
One of them was Danielle Malfavon, 42, of Menifee, who stood clutching a flag among a large group of people along Encanto Drive, a few hundred yards from the mortuary where family and close friends of the Ruiz family were gathering.
Malfavon is part of a running group that includes Lorelyn, Ruiz’s wife.
“I am so proud of Menifee and the greater area,” Malfavon said. “There’s been a lot of tragedies and stuff that happens. But as a town we just pull together for every single thing.”
The ballcap that shielded Malfavon’s eyes from the sun read: U.S. Marine Corps the few, the proud. Malfavon said her husband, Jerry, served in the Marines, as did other relatives from both sides of their family.
“I’m proud to wear this hat today,” she said.
Nearer to the mortuary, Lorraine Quiñones held a two-sided sign bearing Bible passages and a boot-camp picture of Ruiz. She said she is his cousin and was at the house of Ruiz’s mother, who also lives in Menifee, earlier in the morning.
Quiñones said literally hundreds of people were at the house last weekend.
“We have a big extended family,” said Quiñones, who came from Los Angeles with her three children. “But it’s like we’re one nuclear, immediate family. It’s really hit us hard.”
As the caravan accompanying the hearse, which included a handful of motorcycles from the Patriot Guard Riders, traveled south along the 215, small details of first reponders paid their respects.
Three firefighters stood on top of a fire engine on the Highway 74 west overpass of the I-215 in Perris with a 3-by-5-foot American flag -- the sound of the steady stream of traffic below punctuated by honking horns.
“We’re seeing lots of thumbs up and peace signs,” said Michael Kittell, a Cal Fire/Riverside County Fire Department paramedic.
A couple of Riverside County Sheriff's Department units were parked behind the fire engine. There was a similar fire and police department presence at the Nuevo Road overpass and a handful of police officers, their cars parked off to the side, stood at the Ethanac Road overpass, where the procession of vehicles and motorcycles escorting the hearse exited the freeway.
The hearse pulled up to Evans-Brown Mortuary a little before 10:15 a.m. A helicopter buzzed overhead.
Members of the Patriot Guard Riders carried the wooden box containing Ruiz’s remains inside. Those assembled along the walkway grew quiet.
Someone called out: “We love you, Christopher.”
Traci Welsh, 52, spoke for many of the local residents who took time out of their weekends to come down.
“I think Menifee coming together as a community, it’s the least we can do,” she said. “He and his family sacrificed for our freedom. What's an hour of our time.”
